div.head: Restoration of Public Lands of the Municipium Canusinum

p.seg: A single boundary marker discovered in the area of Canusium (mod. Canosa in Italy) attests to the restoration of the boundaries of public lands belonging to Canusium. The restoration is attributed to the emperor Vespasian, and is said to have been done “according to the public maps” (ex formis publicis). Presumably, this means copies of original survey maps were requested from Rome, and these were then used in a survey aimed at restoring the old boundaries. Compare the redemarcation of the centuriated territory of Arausio (mod. Orange in France), in accordance with maps provided by the emperor Vespasian (Piganiol 1962). This process was no doubt necessitated by a dispute, but the details are lost to us. The text provides no insight into the mechanisms whereby this process was accomplished, nor the personnel who were involved.

div.head: DOC112: EDH HD019435; Chelotti 1985 no. 10; AE 1945.85.

div.p: The emperor Caesar Vespasian Augustus, consul 7 times, restored the boundaries of the public fields of Municipium Canusinum according to the public maps.
